The friends enjoyment of the story, and any "praise" given to it, were also removed. "he liked it because" was excised, and already revised "praise we can give to it" ("thing that can be said to its favour" upon initial inscription") was changed to "and we can quite believe it." The passage was relocated to before "Indeed" and the sentence "England is the home of lost ideas" was added after the "produced" (altered from "possible") . England is the home of lost ideas.As for that great and dailyincreasing school of novelists for whom the sun always rises in the East-End, the only thing that can be said about them James writes fiction as if it was were a painful duty, and wastes upon mean motives and imperceptible 'points of view' his neat literary style, his felicitous phrases, his swift and subtle caustic satire. Mr. Hall Caine, it is true, aims at the grandiose, but then he writes at the top of his voice. He is so loud that one cannot hear what he says.Journalist, biographer, and friend of "one of Wilde's favourite poets, Dante Gabriel Rossetti," Wilde was (reportedly) critical of his Recollections of Dante Gabriel Rossetti immediately following the poets death, and scathingly critiqued his biography of Samuel Taylor Coleredge in a review (Guy 367).Mr. James Payn is an adept in the art of concealing what is not worth finding. He hunts down the obvious with the enthusiasm of a short-sighted detective. As one turns over the pages, the suspense of the author becomes almost unbearable. James Payn, prolific mid-nineteenth century journalist, poet, essayist, and novelist.The horses of Mr. William Black's phaeton do not soar towards the sun.Scottish writer of what, as Guy explains, was "disparanglinly referred to as the Kailyard (or cabbage-patch) School" (368). Also a pun on the myth of Phaeton. They merely frighten the sky at evening into violent chromolithographic effects.Per the Clarck Art Museum: "Chromolithography is a term used for color lithographs characterized by saturated, high-gloss color, usually covering the entire sheet. Although color lithography and chromolithography are made by the same technique, their visual results‚Äîand uses‚Äîcontrast greatly. Chromolithographs, known familiarly as ‚Äúchromos,‚Äù were typically associated with popular art and decorative materials: trade cards, children‚Äôs books, and reproductive prints of paintings. As mass-produced products, chromolithographs were printed widely to meet consumer demand. While this made artistic images available‚Äîand affordable‚Äîto many, these works were perceived without the aura of exclusivity or creativity of fine-art color lithographs." Wilde once used the term to disparaginly describe the methoeds of Scottish novelists (Reviews 163; Guy 368). The following passage about local colour" closely echoes his earlier critique of Scottish novelists, and may be yet another instance of his "Self-plagiarism," or adaptive revision of his other works, demonstrating a self-reflexive dimension to his "creative ecology" (Van Hulle). https://www.clarkart.edu/microsites/hue-cry/chromolithography#:~:text=Chromolithography%20is%20a%20term%20used,%E2%80%94and%20uses%E2%80%94contrast%20greatly. On seeing them approach, the peasants take refuge in dialect. Mrs.. Oliphant prattles pleasantlyScottish novelist Margaret Oliphant about curates, lawn-tennis parties, domesticity, and other wearisome things.Mr.. Marion Crawford has immolatedAs Guy notes, "a popular and prolific ex-patriot American author and historian" (368). himself upon the altar of local colour. He is like the lady in the French comedy who keeps talking about "'"le beau ciel d'Italie."'" Besides, he has fallen into a bad habit of uttering moral platitudes. He is always telling us that to be good is to be good, and that to be bad is to be wicked. At times he is always edifying. 'Robert Elsmere' is,Wilde's revised criticisms of the Mary Ward's novel occur both before and after his initial composition of the first version of Dorian Gray in 1890. As Andrew Elfenbein has persausively argued in "On the Discrimination of Influences‚Äù (MLQ, esp. 496-505), Wilde's novel simultaneously mocks and adopts certain textual features of teh extremely popular novel, illustrating the complex "influece" of reading on composition. Wilde's iterative passes at this part of the essay not only suggests a clear preoccupation with novel in fashion that materially substantiates Elfenbein's claims, but also, as an illustration of Van Hulle's notion of creative concurrence, materializes in a confluence of creative activity the social, dialectic nature of writing (and literary influence, as Elfenbein argues). of course, a masterpiece,‚Äîa masterpiece of the "'"genre ennuyeux,"'" the only one form of literature that English people seem to thoroughly enjoy. A thoughtful young friend of ours once told us that it reminded him of the sort of conversation that goes on at a meat tea in the house of a serious Nonconformist family, and we can quite believe it. "A meat-tea was a more substantial meal takien later in the day, and is used by W to indicate the indicate the eating habits of the lower classes or of those who disregarded, or wer ignorant of, the rules of etiquette which governed polite society. . .Nonconformist was a broad term in the 19th century to refer to a variety of of Protestant sects whcih defined themselves in opposition to the teachings of the Anglican or established chruch; in Culture and Anarchy (1869) Matthew Arnold identified nonconformiism with pronvincialism and culgarity, and criticized its partisan tendencies as culturally divisive.Indeed it is only in England that such a book is would could be possible produced.This passage underwent revisions in in each iteration of the essay. Wilde first expanded the Berg version, introducing the "friend" framework, when drafting this fair-copy version. Then, when restoring the ommitted passage for Intentions, he changed the language to include Cyril: "mine" was changed to "ours" and me to "us". The friends enjoyment of the story, and any "praise" given to it, were also removed. "he liked it because" was excised, and already revised "praise we can give to it" ("thing that can be said to its favour" upon initial inscription") was changed to "and we can quite believe it." The passage was relocated to before "Indeed" and the sentence "England is the home of lost ideas" was added after the "produced" (altered from "possible") It reads like a extracts from the sort of conversation that goes on at a meat-tea in the house of a serious Nonconformist family. A thoughtful young friend of mine once told me that he liked it because it reminded him of the sort of conversation that goes on at a meat-tea in the house of a serious Nonconformist family, and this is perhaps the highest thingthat can be said in its favour.praise that we can give to it.England is the home of lost ideas.As for that great and daily-increasing school of novelists for whom the sun always rises in the East-End, the only thing that can be said about them James writes fiction as if it was a painful duty, and wastes upon mean motives and imperceptible 'points of view' his neat literary style, his felicitous phrases, his swift and subtle caustic satire. Also a pun on the myth of Phaeton.Per the Clarck Art Museum: "Chromolithography is a term used for color lithographs characterized by saturated, high-gloss color, usually covering the entire sheet. Although color lithography and chromolithography are made by the same technique, their visual results‚Äîand uses‚Äîcontrast greatly. Chromolithographs, known familiarly as ‚Äúchromos,‚Äù were typically associated with popular art and decorative materials: trade cards, children‚Äôs books, and reproductive prints of paintings. As mass-produced products, chromolithographs were printed widely to meet consumer demand. While this made artistic images available‚Äîand affordable‚Äîto many, these works were perceived without the aura of exclusivity or creativity of fine-art color lithographs." This is no isolated instance that we are giving. It is simply one example out of many;, and if something cannot be done to check, or at least to modify, our monstrous worship of facts, aArt will become sterile, and bBeauty will pass away from the land." '"Even Mr. Robert Louis Stevenson, that exquisite delightful master of delicate and fanciful prose, is tainted with this modern vice, for there is we know no other name for it. There is such a thing as robbing a story of its reality by trying to make it too true, and 'The Black Arrow' is so inartisticSerialized in 1883. Published as a book in 1888. As Guy notes, Wilde wrote to Ross from Reading Gaol, "complaining about the state of the prison library and suggesting that he might present thre authorities with 'a dozen good novels', including 'Stevenson (none here but the Black Arrow!)'" (Guy 367, quoting H & H-D, 646, 790). that it does not contain a single anachronism to boast of, while the transformation of Dr. Jekyll reads dangerously like an experiment out of The the Lancet. As for Mr Rider Haggard, who really has, or had once, the makings of a perfectly magnificent liar, he is now so afraid of being suspected of genius that when he does tell us anything marvellous, he feels bound to invent a personal reminiscence, and to put it into a footnote as a kindBoth Guy and Schroeder suggest that ilde was likely interested in the (accurate) accusations of plagiarism levied at Haggard in the Pall Mall Gazette. Guy and Schroeder both identify Haggard's novels Allan Quatermain and Maiwa's Revenge as the alluded to works containing footnotes. While Guy notes that footnotes contain "information. . .derived from Haggard's own inexperience of Africa," which would suggest the jab at their inclusion being to sere as "cowardly corroboration," Schroeder argues that many of the footnotes in Maiwa's Revenge are "mock-serious," and that "Wilde must have enjoyed [them] and. . .is here criticizing tongue-and-cheek" (Guy 367, Schroeder 29). of cowardly corroboration. Nor are our other novelists much better. Mr. Henry Typesetter signature, "Bradley" in pencilcontradicting people who are much younger than himself, and often ends by writing novels which are so like life thatno one can possibly believe in their probability. This is no isolated instance that we are giving. It is simply one example out of many, and if something cannot be done to check, or at least to modify, our monstrous worship of facts, Art will become sterile, and Beauty will pass away from the land. "Even Mr. Robert Louis Stevenson, that delightful master of delicate and fanciful prose, is tainted with this modern vice, for we know positively no other name for it. Nor are our other novelists much better. Mr. Henry rich rhythmic utterances, and in neither case will the casual inspiration of the moment suffice. Here, as elsewhere, practice must precede perfection. But in modern days while the fashion of reading writing poetry has become far too common, and should, if possible, be discouraged, the fashion of lying has almost fallen into disrepute. Many a young man starts in life with a natural gift for exaggeration which, if nurtured in congenial and sympathetic surroundings, or by the imitation of the best models, might grow into something really great and wonderful. But, as a rule, he comes to nothing. He either falls into careless habits of accuracy....----"' Cyril. My dear Vivian! Vivian. Please don't interrupt in the middle of a sentence. "'He either falls into careless habits of accuracy, or takes to frequenting the society of the aged and the well-informed. Both things are equally fatal to his imagination, as indeed they would be fatal to the imagination of anybody, and in a short time he develops amorbid and unhealthy faculty of truth-telling, begins to verify all statements made in his presence, has no hesitation in rich rhythmic utterances, and in neither case will the casual inspiration of the moment suffice. Here, as elsewhere, practice must precede perfection. But in modern days while the fashion of writing poetry has become far too common, and should, if possible be discouraged, the fashion of lying has almost fallen into disrepute. Many a young man starts in life with a natural gift of exaggeration which, if nurtured in congenial and sympathetic surroundings, or by the imitation of the best models, might grow into something really great and wonderful. But, as a rule, he comes to nothing. He either falls into careless habits of accuracy----" Cyril. My dear fellow ! Vivian. Please don't interrupt in the middle of a sentence. "He either falls into careless habits of accuracy, or takes to frequenting the society of the aged and the well-informed. Both things are equally fatal to his imagination, as indeed they would be fatal to the imagination of anybody, and in a short time he develops amorbid and unhealthy faculty of truth-telling, begins to verify all statements made in his presence, has no hesitation in rich rhythmic utterances, and in neither case will the casual inspiration of the moment suffice. Here, as elsewhere, practice must precede perfection. But in modern days while the fashion of writing poetry has become far too common, and should, if possible, be discouraged, the fashion of lying has almost fallen into disrepute. Many a young man starts in life with a natural gift for of exaggeration which, if nurtured in congenial and sympathetic surroundings, or by the imitation of the best models, might grow into something really great and wonderful. But, as a rule, he comes to nothing. He either falls into careless habits of accuracy----'" Cyril. My dear fellow Vivian! Vivian. Please don't interrupt in the middle of a sentence. "He either falls into careless habits of accuracy, or takes to frequenting the society of the aged and the well-informed. Both things are equally fatal to his imagination, as indeed they would be fatal to the imagination of anybody, and in a short time he develops amorbid and unhealthy faculty of truth-telling, begins to verify all statements made in his presence, has no hesitation in into which he peers with his microscope. He is to be found at the LibrairieAs Guy notes, Wilde presumably means the national library, the Bilotheque Nationale, in Paris. Nationale, or at the British Museum,Schroeder argues that this passage was the basis for a passage in Max Beerbom's Parody of 1893 parody "Oscar Wilde." See Anglo-American Times, 25 March 1893 and Schroeder 28. shamelessly reading up his subject. He has not even the courage of other people's Guy notes that this may have been an allusion to Whistler, who had previously accused Wilde of plagiarism and would later accuse him of plagiarizing "The Decay of Lying" from his Lectures. This prompted a series of additions to the Intentions edition of "The Decay of Lying" directed at Whilster. ideas, but insists on going directly to life for everything, and ultimately, between eEncyclop√¶dias and personal experience, he comes to the ground, having drawn his types from the family circle or from the weekly washerwoman,Possible allusion to Zola's L'Assomoir and having acquired an amount of useful information from which never, even in his most meditative moments, can he thoroughly free himself." '"The loss that results to literature in general fromthis false ideal of our time can hardly be overestimated. People have a careless way of talking about a 'born liar,' just as they talk about a 'born poet.' But in both cases they are wrong. Lying and pPoetry are arts,--arts, as Plato saw, not unconnected with each other,--and they require the most careful study,Reference to The Republic, Book 10, 595 ff. (Guy 366). One can trace the connection between lying and poetry to "poiesis," derived from the Greek "œÄŒøŒπŒµ·øñŒΩ" or "to make." I.e, both are acts of creating something wholly new, which Wilde continues to position in opposition to realism or naturalism's mimitec attempts at REpresentation. See also the addition to Folio 53. the most disinterested devotion. Indeed, they have their technique, just as the more material arts of painting and sculpture have, their subtle secrets of form and colour, their craft-mysteries, their deliberate artistic methods. As one knows the poet by his fine music, so one can recognise the lLiar by his into which he peers with his microscope. He is to be found at the LibrairieAs Guy notes, Wilde presumably means the national library, the Bilotheque Nationale, in Paris. Nationale, or at the British Museum,Schroeder argues that this passage was the basis for a passage in Max Beerbom's Parody of 1893 parody "Oscar Wilde." See Anglo-American Times, 25 March 1893 and Schroeder 28. shamelessly reading up his subject. He has not even the courage of other people's Guy notes that this may have been an allusion to Whistler, who had previously accused Wilde of plagiarism and would later accuse him of plagiarizing "The Decay of Lying" from his Lectures. This prompted a series of additions to the Intentions edition of "The Decay of Lying" directed at Whilster. ideas, but insists on going directly to life for everything, and ultimately, between encyclop√¶dias and personal experience, he comes to the ground, having drawn his types from the family circle or from the weekly washerwoman,Possible allusion to Zola's L'Assomoir and having acquired an amount of useful information from which never, even in his most meditative moments, can he thoroughly free himself. "The loss that results to literature in general fromthis false ideal of our time can hardly be over-estimated. People have a careless way of talking about a 'born liar,' just as they talk about a 'born poet.' But in both cases they are wrong. Lying and poetry are arts--arts, as Plato saw, not unconnected with each other--and they require the most careful study,Reference to The Republic, Book 10, 595 ff. (Guy 366). One can trace the connection between lying and poetry to "poiesis," derived from the Greek "œÄŒøŒπŒµ·øñŒΩ" or "to make." I.e, both are acts of creating something wholly new, which Wilde continues to position in opposition to realism or naturalism's mimitec attempts at REpresentation. See also the addition to Folio 53. the most disinterested devotion. Indeed, they have their technique, just as the more material arts of painting and sculpture have, their subtle secrets of form and colour, their craft-mysteries, their deliberate artistic methods. As one knows the poet by his fine music, so one can recognise the liar by his into which he peers with his microscope. He is to be found at the LibrairieAs Guy notes, Wilde presumably means the national library, the Bilotheque Nationale, in Paris. Nationale, or at the British Museum,Schroeder argues that this passage was the basis for a passage in Max Beerbom's Parody of 1893 parody "Oscar Wilde." See Anglo-American Times, 25 March 1893 and Schroeder 28. shamelessly reading up his subject. He has not even the courage of other people's Guy notes that this may have been an allusion to Whistler, who had previously accused Wilde of plagiarism and would later accuse him of plagiarizing "The Decay of Lying" from his Lectures. This prompted a series of additions to the Intentions edition of "The Decay of Lying" directed at Whilster. ideas, but insists on going directly to life for everything, and ultimately, between encyclop√¶dias and personal experience, he comes to the ground, having drawn his types from the family circle or from the weekly washerwoman,Possible allusion to Zola's L'Assomoir and having acquired an amount of useful information from which never, even in his most meditative moments, can he thoroughly free himself. "'The loss that results to literature in general fromthis false ideal of our time can hardly be over-estimated. People have a careless way of talking about a 'born liar,' just as they talk about a 'born poet.' But in both cases they are wrong. "The loss that results to literature in general fromthis false ideal of our time can hardly be overestimated. People have a careless way of talking about a 'born liar,' just as they talk about a 'born poet.' But in both cases they are wrong. Lying and Poetry are arts,arts, as Plato saw not unconnected with each other,and they require the most careful study,Reference to The Republic, Book 10, 595 ff. (Guy 366). We are. That is one of the objects of the cClub. Now, if you promise not to interrupt too muchoften, I will read you my article. Cyril. (flinging himself down upon the sofa).(flinging himself down on the sofa.)In the cut directions, Cyril takes a characteristically decadent position, like that of ‚ÄúA Decadent Girl‚Äù (1899) by Ram√≥n Casas (1866-1932). https://melbourneartclass.com/the-art-of-fin-de-siecle/ All right. Vivian. (reading in a very clear, musical voice.). 'The Decay of Lying: A Protest.-- "One of the chief causes of the curiously commonplace character of most of the literature of our age is undoubtedly the decay of Llying as an art, a science, and a social pleasure. The ancient historians gave us delightful fiction in the form of fact,; the modern novelist gives presents us with dull facts under the guise of fiction. The bBlue-book isReferring to government publications of official reports, which had blue bindings. rapidly becoming his ideal both for method and manner. He has his tedious 'document humain,' his miserable little 'coin de la cr√©ation'One of the many references to Zola as the figure head of literary naturalism. who is of the usual age. Cyril. Vivian. (reading in a very clear, musical voice) "The Decay of Lying: A Protest.-- One of the chief causes that can be assigned for the curiously commonplace character of most of the literature of our age is undoubtedly the decay of Lying as an art, a science, and a social pleasure. The ancient historians gave us delightful fiction in the form of fact; the modern novelist presents us with dull facts under the guise of fiction. The Blue-Book isReferring to government publications of official reports, which had blue bindings. rapidly becoming his ideal both for method and manner. Vivian. (reading in a very clear, musical voice.). 'The Decay of Lying: A Protest. "One of the chief causes of the curiously commonplace character of most of the literature of our age is undoubtedly the decay of lLying as an art, a science, and a social pleasure. The ancient historians gave us delightful fiction in the form of facts, the modern novelist gives presents us with dull facts under the guise of fiction. No:, the politicians won't do,and besides, what I am pleading for is Llying in Aart. Shall I read you what I have written? It might do you a great deal of good. Typesetters Signature: ShawCyril. Certainly, if you give me a cigarette. Thanks. By the way, what magazine do you intend it for? Vivian. For the Retrospective ReviewRetrospective Review. The revival Vivian refers to is an invention. As Josephine Guy notes, "the original Retrospective Review, founded in 180 and runnign until 1828, dealt with historical and antiquarian subjects; a second Retrospective Review--which (according to Evans) consisted of criticism of, and extracts from, curious and rare books--was briefly published in 1853-4 (Evans 295)" (Guy 364).I think I told you we had revived it. Cyril. Whom do you mean by 'we'? Vivian. Oh, The Tired Hedonists of course. It is a club to which I belong. We are supposed to wear faded roses inroses were frequently associated with Aestheticism, and particularly Walter Pater (usually satirical; see "Mr Rose" by W.H. Mallock in The New Republic. See Guy 364. our button-holes when we meet, and to have a sort of cult for Domitian.Roman emperor "renowned for cruelty and decadent behavior"; referenced in both Dorian Gray and in letter describing a friend, "perhaps Lord Alfred Douglas" (Guy 364). I am afraid you are not eligible. You are too fond of simple pleasures. Cyril. I should be black-balled on the ground of animal spirits, I suppose? Vivian. Probably. Besides, you are a little too old. We don't admit anyone over thirty, as you are well speak the truth atonce. No, the politicians won't do,. Something may, perhaps, be urged on behalf of the Bar. The mantle of the Sophist has fallen on its members. Their feigned ardours and unreal rhetoric are delightful. They can make the worse appear the better cause, as though they were fresh from Leontine schools,"Ancient schools of rhetoric located in Leontini in Sicily" (Guy 364) and have been known to wrest from reluctant juries triumphant verdicts of acquittal for their clients, even when those clients, as often happens, were clearly and unmistakeably innocent. But they are briefed by the prosaic, and are not ashamed to appeal to precedent. In spite of their endeavours, the truth will out. Newspapers, even, have degenerated. They may now be absolutely relied upon. One feels it as one wades through their columns. It is always the unreadable that occurs. I am afraid that there is not much to be said in favour of either the lawyer or the journalist. besides, what I am pleading for is Lying in art. Shall I read you what I have written? It might do you a great deal of good. Typesetters Signature: ShawCyril. Certainly, if you give me a cigarette. Thanks. By the way, what magazine do you intend it for? Vivian. I am afraid you are not eligible. You are too fond of simple pleasures. Cyril. I should be black-balled on the ground of animal spirits, I suppose? Vivian. Probably. Besides, you are a little too old. We dont admit anyone over thirty, as you are Vivian. Who wants to be consistent?See also "The Critic as Artist": "we are never more true to ourselves than when we are inconsistent" (Schroeder 27). The dullard and the doctrinaire., the tedious people who carry out their principles to the bitter end of action, to the reductio ad absurdum of practice. Not I. Like Emerson, I write over the door of my library the word " "Whim."A reference to Ralph Waldo Emerson's "Self-Reliance." In the essay, Emerson writes that the two "terrors" of self-reliance are conformity and consistency. He writes: "The other terror that scares us from self-trust is our consistency; a reverence for our past act or word, because the eyes of others have no other data for computing our orbit than our past acts, and we are loath to disappoint them. . . A foolish consistency is the hobgoblin of little minds, adored by little statesmen and philosophers and divines. With consistency a great soul has simply nothing to do. He may as well concern himself with his shadow on the wall. Speak what you think now in hard words, and to-morrow speak what to-morrow thinks in hard words again, though it contradict every thing you said to-day.--'Ah, so you shall be sure to be misunderstood.'--Is it so bad, then, to be misunderstood? Pythagoras was misunderstood, and Socrates, and Jesus, and Luther, and Copernicus, and Galileo, and Newton, and every pure and wise spirit that ever took flesh. To be great is to be misunderstood." Guy notes that Wilde frequently referenced Emerson throughout his career, and even requested a volume of his essays while in prison. Besides, my article is really a most salutary and valuable warning. If it is attended to, there may be a new Renaissance of Art.See also Wilde's 1882 lecture "The English Renaissance of Art" for a similar argument (Guy 363). Cyril. What is the subject.? Vivian. I intend to call it 'The Decay of Lying: A Protest.' Cyril. The decay of Lying! I should have thought that our politicians kept up that art habit. Vivian. I assure you that they do not. They never rise beyond the level of misrepresentation, and actually condescend to prove, to discuss, to argue. How different from the temper of the true liar, with his frank, fearless statements, his superb irresponsibility, his healthy, natural disdain of proof of any kind.! After all, what is a fine lie? Simply that which is its own evidence.Schroeder suggests this is a reformulation of Byron's Don Juan, Canto XI, stanza 37: "And, after all, what is alie? 'Tis but /The truth in masquerade." If a man is sufficiently unimaginative to produce evidence in support of a lie, he might just as Vivian. Who wants to be consistent?See also "The Critic as Artist": "we are never more true to ourselves than when we are inconsistent" (Schroeder 27). The dullard and the doctrinaire, the tedious people who carry out their principles to the bitter end of action, to the reductio ad absurdum of practice. Not I. Like Emerson, I write over the door of my library the word " "Whim."A reference to Ralph Waldo Emerson's "Self-Reliance." In the essay, Emerson writes that the two "terrors" of self-reliance are conformity and consistency. He writes: "The other terror that scares us from self-trust is our consistency; a reverence for our past act or word, because the eyes of others have no other data for computing our orbit than our past acts, and we are loath to disappoint them. . . A foolish consistency is the hobgoblin of little minds, adored by little statesmen and philosophers and divines. With consistency a great soul has simply nothing to do. He may as well concern himself with his shadow on the wall. Speak what you think now in hard words, and to-morrow speak what to-morrow thinks in hard words again, though it contradict every thing you said to-day.--'Ah, so you shall be sure to be misunderstood.'--Is it so bad, then, to be misunderstood? Pythagoras was misunderstood, and Socrates, and Jesus, and Luther, and Copernicus, and Galileo, and Newton, and every pure and wise spirit that ever took flesh. To be great is to be misunderstood." They never rise beyond the level of misrepresentation, and actually condescend to prove, to discuss, to argue. A foolish consistency is the hobgoblin of little minds, adored by little statesmen and philosophers and divines. With consistency a great soul has simply nothing to do. They never rise beyond the level of misrepresentation, and actually condescend to prove, to discuss, to argue. How different from the temper of the true liar, with his frank, fearless statements, his superb irresponsibility, his healthy, natural disdain of proof of any kind! After all, what is a fine lie? Simply that which is its own evidence.Schroeder suggests this is a reformulation of Byron's Don Juan, Canto XI, stanza 37: "And, after all, what is alie? 'Tis but /The truth in masquerade." If a man is sufficiently unimaginative to produce evidence in support of a lie, he might just as Vivianivian. Who wants to be consistent?See also "The Critic as Artist": "we are never more true to ourselves than when we are inconsistent" (Schroeder 27). The dullard and the doctrinaire., the tedious people who carry out their principles to the bitter end of action, to the reductio ad absurdum of practice. Not I. Like Emerson, I write over the door of my library the word " "Whim."A reference to Ralph Waldo Emerson's "Self-Reliance." In the essay, Emerson writes that the two "terrors" of self-reliance are conformity and consistency. He writes: "The other terror that scares us from self-trust is our consistency; a reverence for our past act or word, because the eyes of others have no other data for computing our orbit than our past acts, and we are loath to disappoint them. . . A foolish consistency is the hobgoblin of little minds, adored by little statesmen and philosophers and divines. With consistency a great soul has simply nothing to do. He may as well concern himself with his shadow on the wall. Speak what you think now in hard words, and to-morrow speak what to-morrow thinks in hard words again, though it contradict every thing you said to-day.--'Ah, so you shall be sure to be misunderstood.'--Is it so bad, then, to be misunderstood? Pythagoras was misunderstood, and Socrates, and Jesus, and Luther, and Copernicus, and Galileo, and Newton, and every pure and wise spirit that ever took flesh. To be great is to be misunderstood." Guy notes that Wilde frequently referenced Emerson throughout his career, and even requested a volume of his essays while in prison. Besides,, my article is really a most salutary and valuable warning. If it is attended to, there may be a new Renaissance of Art.See also Wilde's 1882 lecture "The English Renaissance of Art" for a similar argument (Guy 363). Cyrilyril. What is the subject.? Vivianivian. I intend to call it "'The Decay of Lying: A Protest.'" Cyrilyril. The decay of Lying! I should have thought that our politicians kept up that art habit. Vivianivian. I assure you that they do not. They never rise beyond the level of misrepresentation, and actually condescend to prove, to discuss, to argue. How different from the temper of the true liar, with his frank, fearless statements, his superb irresponsibility, his healthy, natural disdain of proof of any kind.! After all, what is a fine lie? Simply that which is its own evidence.Schroeder suggests this is a reformulation of Byron's Don Juan, Canto XI, stanza 37: "And, after all, what is alie? 'Tis but /The truth in masquerade." If a man is sufficiently unimaginative to produce evidence in support of a lie, he might just as Vivian. In the essay, Emerson writes that the two "terrors" of self-reliance are conformity and consistency. He writes: "The other terror that scares us from self-trust is our consistency; a reverence for our past act or word, because the eyes of others have no other data for computing our orbit than our past acts, and we are loath to disappoint them. . . A foolish consistency is the hobgoblin of little minds, adored by little statesmen and philosophers and divines. With consistency a great soul has simply nothing to do. He may as well concern himself with his shadow on the wall. Speak what you think now in hard words, and to-morrow speak what to-morrow thinks in hard words again, though it contradict every thing you said to-day.--'Ah, so you shall be sure to be misunderstood.'--Is it so bad, then, to be misunderstood? Pythagoras was misunderstood, and Socrates, and Jesus, and Luther, and Copernicus, and Galileo, and Newton, and every pure and wise spirit that ever took flesh. To be great is to be misunderstood." They never rise beyond the level of misrepresentation, and actually condescend to prove, to discuss, to argue. If a man is sufficiently unimaginative to produce evidence in support of a lie he might just as EgoismEgotism itself, which is so essential necessary to the a proper sense of human dignity, is absolutely the result of indoor life. Out of doors one becomes abstract and impersonal. One's individuality absolutely leaves one. And then nature is so indifferent, so unappreciative. Whenever I am walking in the park here, I always feel that I am no more to natureher than the cattle that browse on the slope, or the burdock that blooms in the ditch. Nothing is more evident than that Nature hates Mmind. Thinking is the most unhealthy thing in the world, and people die of it just as of any other disease. Fortunately, in England at least, it is not catching. Our splendid physique as a nation people is entirely due to our national stupidity. I only hope we shall be able to keep this great historic bulwark of our happiness for many years to come;, but I am afraid that we are beginning to be becoming over-educated;Guy suggests that this may be a reference to the ongoing discourse on education reforms taking place in the Nineteenth Century. See also Guy, ‚ÄúSelf-Plagiarism, Creativity and Craftsmanship in Oscar Wilde.‚Äù English Literature in Transition, 1880-1920, no. 41, 1998, pp. 6‚Äì23. at least everybody who is incapable of learning has taken to teaching.--that is really what our enthusiasm for education has come to. In the meantimewhile, you had better go back to your wearisome uncomfortable Nature, and leave me to correct my proofs. Cyril. Writing an [illegible] article! That is not very consistent after what you have just said. Egotism itself, which is so necessary to a proper sense of human dignity, is entirely the result of indoor life. Out of doors one becomes abstract and impersonal. One's individuality absolutely leaves one. And then Nature is so indifferent, so unappreciative. Whenever I am walking in the park here, I always feel that I am no more to her her than the cattle that browse on the slope, or the burdock that blooms in the ditch. Nothing is more evident than that Nature hates Mind. Thinking is the most unhealthy thing in the world, and people die of it just as they die of any other disease. Fortunately, in England at any rate, thought is not catching. Our splendid physique as a people is entirely due to our national stupidity. In the meanwhile, you had better go back to your wearisome uncomfortable Nature, and leave me to correct my proofs. Cyril. Writing an [illegible] article! That is not very consistent after what you have just said. I look at a landscape I cannot help seeing all its defects. It is fortunate for us, however, that Nature is so imperfect, as otherwise we shouldwould have had no aAart at all. Art is our spirited protest, our gallant attempt to teach Nature her proper place. As for the infinite variety of Nature, that is a pure myth.Schroeder argues that this is both a challenging of John Addington Symonds 1887 assertion that "t will never match the infinite variety and subtlety of nature; no drawing or painting will equal the primary beauties of the living model' (The Model', Fortnightly Review , vol.42, (Dec. 1887), p 859) and an allusiton to Shakespeare's Antony and Cleopatra, II.ii.239 f. It is not to be found in Nature herself it self but, in the imagination, or fancy, or cultivated blindness whim of the man who looks at her. C.Cyril. Well, you need not look at the landscape. You can lie on the grass and smoke and talk. V. Vivian. But nature is so uncomfortable. Grass is hard and lumpy and damp, and full of dreadful black insects. that are always stinging poor humanity, in order to show their gratitude to their Creator. Why, even MapleLarge commercial furniture firm, located at Tottenham Court Road. Guy identifies the reference as an allusion to "the simple, inexpensive, black-stained rush-bottomed 'Sussex' chairs" sold by Morris & Co., "a firm established by poet, painter, and designer William Morris" (362).can make you a more comfortable seat than the whole of nature can. Nature pales before the Tottenham Court Road. The addition I don't complain. If nature had been comfortable, mankind would never have invented architecture, and I prefer houses to the open air. In a house we all feel of the proper proportions. Everything is subordinated to us, fashioned for our use and our pleasure. I look at a landscape I cannot help seeing all its defects. It is fortunate for us, however, that Nature is so imperfect, as otherwise we should have had no art at all. Art is our spirited protest, our gallant attempt to teach Nature her proper place. The Decay of Lying:a Dialogue.Scene. --The Library of a Country House in England. Persons. -- Cyril and Vivian. Cyril (coming in through the open window from the terrace.). My dear Vivian, don't coop yourself up all day in the library. It is a perfectly lovely afternoon. Let us go and lie on the grass, and smoke cigarettes and enjoy ature. Vivian. Enjoy nature! My dear Cyril I am glad to say that I have entirely lost that faculty. People tell us that art makes us love nature more than we loved her before,; that it reveals nature her secrets to us,; and that after a careful study of Corot and Constable we see Tthings in her that had escaped us. My own experience is that the more we study at, the less we care for nature. What art really reveals to us is nature's lack of design, her curious crudities, her extraordinary monotony, her absolutely unfinished condition. When The Decay of Lying:an Observationa Dialogue.Persons: Cyril and Vivian. Scene:The Library of a Country House in Nottinghamshire Cyril (coming in through the open window from the terrace.). My dear Vivian, don't coop yourself up all day in the library. It is a perfectly lovely afternoon. The air is exquisite. There is a mist upon the woods, like the purple bloom upon a plum. Let us go and lie on the grass, and smoke cigarettes, and enjoy Nnature. Vivian. Enjoy Nature! I am glad to say that I have entirely lost that faculty. People tell us that Art makes us love Nature more than we loved her before; that it reveals her secrets to us; and that after a careful study of Corot and Constable we see things in her that had escaped our observation. My own experience is that the more we study At, the less we care for Nature. What Art really reveals to us is Nature's lack of design, her curious crudities, her extraordinary monotony, her absolutely unfinished condition. Nature has good intentions, of course, but, as Aristotle once said, she cannot carry them out. When The Decay of Lying: an Observation a Dialogue. Persons: Cyril and Vivian. Scene : . -- The Library of a Country House in England. Nottinghamshire Persons. -- Cyril and Vivian. Cyril (coming in through the open window from the terrace.). My dear Vivian, don't coop yourself up all day in the library. It is a perfectly lovely afternoon. The air is exquisite. There is a mist upon the woods, like the purple bloom upon a plum. Let us go and lie on the grass, and smoke cigarettes, and enjoy Nnature. Vivian. Enjoy Nnature! I am glad to say that I have entirely lost that faculty. People tell us that Aart makes us love Nnature more than we loved her before; that it reveals her secrets to us; and that after a careful study of Corot and Constable we see things in her that had escaped us. our observation. My own experience is that the more we study Aat, the less we care for Nnature. What Aart really reveals to us is Nnature's lack of design, her curious crudities, her extraordinary monotony, her absolutely unfinished condition. Nature has good intentions, of course, but, as Aristotle once said, she cannot carry them out. When The Decay of Lying:an Observationa Dialogue. Persons: Cyril and Vivian. Scene:. --The Library of a Country House in England. Nottinghamshire Persons. -- Cyril and Vivian. Cyril (coming in through the open window from the terrace.). My dear Vivian, don't coop yourself up all day in the library. It is a perfectly lovely afternoon. The air is exquisite. There is a mist upon the woods, like the purple bloom upon a plum. Let us go and lie on the grass, and smoke cigarettes, and enjoy Nnature. Vivian. Enjoy Nnature! My dear Cyril I am glad to say that I have entirely lost that faculty. People tell us that Aart makes us love Nnature more than we loved her before,; that it reveals nature her secrets to us,; and that after a careful study of Corot and Constable we see Tthings in her that had escaped us. our observation. My own experience is that the more we study Aat, the less we care for Nnature. What Aart really reveals to us is Nnature's lack of design, her curious crudities, her extraordinary monotony, her absolutely unfinished condition. Nature has good intentions, of course, but, as Aristotle once said, she cannot carry them out. When The Decay of Lying:a Dialogue.Scene.The Library of a Country House in England. Persons. -- Cyril and Vivian. Cyril (coming in through the open window from the terrace.). My dear Vivian, don't coop yourself up all day in the library. It is a perfectly lovely afternoon. Let us go and lie on the grass, and smoke cigarettes and enjoy ature. Vivian. Enjoy nature! My dear Cyril I am glad to say that I have entirely lost that faculty. People tell us that art makes us love nature more than we loved her before, that it reveals nature her secrets to us, and that after a careful study of Corot and Constable we see Things in her that had escaped us. My own experience is that the more we study at, the less we care for nature. What art really reveals to us is nature's lack of design, her curious crudities, her extraordinary monotony, her absolutely unfinished condition. When
